facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 255 of 1964 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 255 of 1964. Appeal by special lea

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated November 14, 1960 of Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 273 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 14, 1960 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 273 of 1959.

facts.text: Under contract dated October 14, 1956, respondent granted right to forest produce from Coupe No. 9, Lendara in Saiura Borgain Reserved Forest in Kanker Forest Division of Bastar District of Madhya Pradesh, for period October 14, 1956 to March 31, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Under a companytract dated October 14. 1956, the respondent was granted a right to the forest produce from Coupe No. 9, Lendara in the Saiura Borgain Reserved Forest in the Kanker Forest Division of Bastar District of Madhya Pradesh, for the period October 14, 1956 to March 31, 1958.

facts.text: Divisional Forest Officer held enquiry for breaches committed by respondent of contract terms.

anchor.surface_text: The Divisional Forest Officer held an enquiry in respect of certain breaches companymitted by the respondent of the terms of the companytract,

facts.text: Divisional Forest Officer by order dated January 30, 1958 directed respondent to pay Rs. 8,500 as compensation under r. 15(1) of Forest Contract Rules for damage in reserved forest and Rs. 500 as penalty under r. 30(1).

anchor.surface_text: and by order dated January 30, 1958 directed the respondent in exercise of the authority under r. 15 1  of the Forest Contract Rules framed by the Government of Cenytral Provinces Berar, to pay Rs. 8,500 as companypensation assessed by him for damage done in the reserved forest and Rs. 500 as penalty under r. 30 1  of the Forest Contract Rules.

facts.text: Appeal against DFO order to Conservator of Forests was unsuccessful.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal against the order to the Conservator of Forests, and a revision petition to the Chief Conservator of Forests, Madhya Pradesh, were unsuccessful.

facts.text: Revision petition to Chief Conservator of Forests, Madhya Pradesh, was unsuccessful.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal against the order to the Conservator of Forests, and a revision petition to the Chief Conservator of Forests, Madhya Pradesh, were unsuccessful.

facts.text: Respondent filed petition under Art. 226 in Madhya Pradesh High Court to quash DFO order dated January 30, 1958 and restrain enforcement.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then moved the High Court of Madhya Pradesh by a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution for a writ quashing the order dated January 30, 1958 directing payment of companypensation and penalty and restraining enforcement of the order.

facts.text: High Court granted the petition, quashed the order, and restrained State and forest authorities from recovering Rs. 9,000.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court granted the petition and restrained the State and the forest authorities from recovering Rs. 9,000, ordered on January 30, 1958, from the respondent.

facts.text: Appellants contended High Court erred in holding Divisional Forest Officer not authorized under r.15 for coupe not in reserved forest.

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal, the appellants companytended in the first instance that the High Court was in error in holding that by r. 15 of the Forest Contract Rules the Divisional Forest Officer was number authorized to direct the companytractor to pay companypensation for damage done by him or his agents or servants, because the companype was number in a reserved forest.

facts.text: Such case that coupe not in reserved forest never pleaded by contractor in petition.

anchor.surface_text: Such a case, it was said, was never pleaded by the companytractor in his petition, and the High Court in granting relief to the respondent made out a case which the appellants had numberopportunity to meet.

facts.text: Notification under S.20 Indian Forest Act declared State forests of Bastar District in Tahsil Kanker Sainmura-Borgaon as reserved forests.

anchor.surface_text: In support of their case that the companype is a part of the reserved forest, the appellants have annexed to their petition for special leave a true companyy of a numberification issued under S. 20 of the Indian Forest Act, 1927, as applied to the Central Provinces, declaring that the State forests of the Bastar District in Tahsil Kanker Sainmura-Borgaon specified in the Schedule shall be reserved forests.

facts.text: Supreme Court agrees with appellants that coupe is part of reserved forest.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the appellants that the High Court has without any plea or evidence assumed that companypensation under r. 15 1  companyld number be directed to be paid by the companytractor for damage done in the companype, for which he was given a companytract, because the companype was number included in a. reserved forest.

facts.text: High Court plea not raised in petition, objections to DFO, appeal to Conservator, or revision to CCF.

anchor.surface_text: The plea which appealed to the High Court was number raised in the petition, number in the objections to the Divisional Forest Officer in reply to the numberice to show cause, number in the memorandum of appeal before the Conservator of Forests, number in the petition invoking the revisional jurisdiction of the Chief Conservator of Forests.

facts.text: Contract makes Forest Contract Rules part of contract via cl.6.

anchor.surface_text: By cl. 6 of the companytract, the Forest Contract Rules framed by the local Government are made part of the companytract.

facts.text: Cl.9 of contract: disputes on interpretation, performance or breach referred to Chief Conservator of Forests, decision final.

anchor.surface_text: In the event of any doubt or dispute arising between the parties as to the interpretation of any of the companyditions of this companytract or as to the performance or breach thereof, the matter shall be referred to the Chief Conservator of Forests, Madhya Pradesh, Nagpur, whose decision shall be final and binding on the parties hereto.

facts.text: R.15(1): Contractor responsible for damage in reserved forest by self/agents/servants; compensation assessed by DFO, final as arbitrator, appeal to Conservator.

anchor.surface_text: 15 1  A forest companytractor shall be responsible for any damage that may be done in a reserved forest by himself or his servants and agents. The companypensation for such damage shall be assessed by the Divisional Forest Officer, whose decision shall be deemed to be that of an arbitrator and shall be final and binding on the parties, except to the extent that it shall be subject to an appeal to the Conservator of Forests.

facts.text: R.30(1): For breach not terminating contract, DFO may recover portion of penalty up to Rs.500 under S.85; appeal if >200.

anchor.surface_text: 30 1  Where the forest companytractor companymits a breach of any of the companyditions of his companytract but it is number proposed to terminate his companytract on account thereof, the whole penalty provided for in rule 28 shall number be recovered from him, but the Divisional Forest Officer shall have power to recover a portion thereof, number exceeding five hundred rupees,

issues.text: Whether the High Court erred in holding that the Divisional Forest Officer was not authorized under r.15 to direct payment of compensation because the coupe was not in a reserved forest

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal, the appellants contended in the first instance that the High Court was in error in holding that by r. 15 of the Forest Contract Rules the Divisional Forest Officer was not authorized to direct the contractor to pay compensation for damage done by him or his agents or servants, because the coupe was not in a reserved forest. Such a case, it was said, was never pleaded by the contractor in his petition, and the High Court in granting relief to the respondent made out a case which the appellants had no opportunity to meet. In support of their case that the coupe is a part of the reserved forest, the appellants have annexed to their petition for special leave a true copy of a notification issued under S. 20 of the Indian Forest Act, 1927, as applied to the Central Provinces, decl

issues.text: Whether the Divisional Forest Officer has authority under r.15(1) to determine whether damage in reserved forest was caused by the contractor or his agents when disputed, or whether such dispute must be referred under cl.9 of the contract to the Chief Conservator

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the respondent it was urged before the High Court, as also before this Court, that where a dispute arose between the Divisional Forest Officer and the contractor, whether the contractor, his servants or agents had caused damage in a reserved forest, the question could be decided in the manner appointed in cl. 9 of the contract alone, i.e., by arbitration of the officer denominated, and not by the Divisional Forest Officer. In dealing with the validity of the order imposing penalty upon the contractor the High Court upheld that argument. Rule 15 in the first instance declares that the forest contractor shall be responsible for any damage done either by himself, or his servants or agents it then proceeds to state that compensation shall be assessed by the Divisional Forest Officer whose decision shall be deemed to be that of an arbitrator subject to an appeal to the Conservator of Forests. The rule does not confer upon the Divisional Forest Officer authority to determine, when a dispute is raised, whether damage has been caused in a reserved forest by the contractor, his agents or his servants.

issues.text: Whether the Divisional Forest Officer has authority under r.30(1) to impose penalty where there is a dispute as to breach of contract, or whether breach determination requires reference under cl.9

anchor.surface_text: The second part of the order imposing penalty under r. 30 1  also suffers from the same infirmity. It is true that under the rule the Divisional Forest Officer had power to impose penalty in a sum not exceeding Rs. 500. But exercise of that power is conditioned by the existence of a breach by the forest contractor of any of the terms of the contract. Where a, dispute arises whether there has been a breach of any of the terms of the contract, it is, for reasons already stated, to be determined by the Chief Conservator of Forests. That has admittedly not been done. The order imposing penalty under r. 30 1  must also be set aside.

issues.text: Whether the Chief Conservator of Forests' decision in revision petition constitutes a decision under cl.9 of the contract as arbitration of the dispute

anchor.surface_text: It was then urged that in any event a decision was in fact given by the Chief Conservator of Forests in this case, and that decision complied with the requirements of cl. 9 of the contract. But as already stated, the Divisional Forest Officer passed an order holding the respondent liable to pay compensation for damage done in a reserved forest and assessing the compensation at Rs. 8,500 and penalty at Rs. That order was confirmed in appeal by the Conservator of Forests, and in exercise of his revisional jurisdiction the Chief Conservator of Forests upheld the order of the Conservator of Forests. The Chief Conservator of Forests did not even purport to act as an arbitrator he recorded no evidence, and expressly held that the Divisional Forest Officer was not obliged to refer the case for arbitration under cl. 9 of the contract, The trial was not of a proceeding in arbitration, but of a proceeding in exercise of supervisory or revisional jurisdiction. If in truth the dispute had to be referred for adjudication to the Chief Conservator of Forests, his decision that he found no reason to interfere with the findings of the Divisional Forest Officer who was one of the parties to the dispute, cannot conceivably be regarded as an award between two contesting parties.

issues.text: Whether there is inconsistency between cl.9 of the contract and r.15 such that contract terms prevail over the rules

anchor.surface_text: It was argued however that by virtue of cl. 6 of the contract, the Forest Contract Rules were made part of the contract, and the Divisional Forest Officer was invested with authority not only to determine the amount of compensation which may be payable by the contractor for damage done in a reserved forest, but also to determine whether the contractor or his agents or servants had been responsible for causing the damage. This, for reasons already stated, we are unable to accept. There is no inconsistency between cl. 9 of the contract and r. 15. It is unnecessary, therefore, to consider whether in case of inconsistency, the terms of the contract expressly setting out a certain covenant may supersede the terms of the rule.

arguments.claim: High Court erred in holding that Divisional Forest Officer was not authorized under r.15 to direct contractor to pay compensation for damage because the coupe was not in a reserved forest; such case never pleaded by contractor; coupe is part of reserved forest per notification under S.20

Such a case, it was said, was never pleaded by the companytractor in his petition, and the High Court in granting relief to the respondent made out a case which the appellants had numberopportunity to meet. In support of their case that the companype is a part of the reserved forest, the appellants have annexed to their petition for special leave a true companyy of a numberification issued under S. 20 of the Indian Forest Act, 1927, as applied to the Central Provinces, declaring that the State forests of the Bastar District in Tahsil Kanker Sainmura-Borgaon specified in the Schedule shall be reserved forests.

But exercise of that power is companyditioned by the existence of a breach by the forest companytractor of any of the terms of the companytract. holdings.text: The High Court erred in holding that the Divisional Forest Officer was not authorized under r.15 to direct payment of compensation because the coupe was not in a reserved forest, as no such plea was raised by the respondent and the coupe is part of the reserved forest.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the appellants that the High Court has without any plea or evidence assumed that compensation under r. 15 1 could not be directed to be paid by the contractor for damage done in the coupe, for which he was given a contract, because the coupe was not included in a. reserved forest. The plea which appealed to the High Court was not raised in the petition, not in the objections to the Divisional Forest Officer in reply to the notice to show cause, not in the memorandum of appeal before the Conservator of Forests, not in the petition invoking the revisional jurisdiction of the Chief Conservator of Forests.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No plea or evidence by respondent; plea not raised in prior proceedings; notification confirms reserved status.

holdings.text: Rule 15(1) does not confer authority on the Divisional Forest Officer to determine, when disputed, whether damage in reserved forest was caused by the contractor, agents or servants; such dispute must be referred under cl.9 to the Chief Conservator.

anchor.surface_text: The rule does not confer upon the Divisional Forest Officer authority to determine, when a dispute is raised, whether damage has been caused in a reserved forest by the contractor, his agents or his servants. The rule only declares that for damage that may be done, by the contractor, his servants or agents, in the forest, the contractor shall be liable the rule also invests the Divisional Forest Officer with authority to determine the amount of compensation payable by the contractor, but not to determine whether the contractor, his servants or his agents have committed breach of the contract.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of r.15 declares responsibility and authorizes assessment of quantum but not disputed causation/breach; cl.9 governs disputes on performance/breach.

holdings.text: There is no inconsistency between cl.9 of the contract and r.15 of the Forest Contract Rules.

anchor.surface_text: There is no inconsistency between cl. 9 of the contract and r. 15. It is unnecessary, therefore, to consider whether in case of inconsistency, the terms of the contract expressly setting out a certain covenant may supersede the terms of the rule.

holdings.reasoning_summary: cl.9 covers disputes on breach; r.15 covers assessment post-liability; harmonious reading possible without conflict.

holdings.text: The Chief Conservator's decision in revisional jurisdiction does not constitute a decision under cl.9 as arbitration; no evidence recorded, not purporting as arbitrator.

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Conservator of Forests did not even purport to act as an arbitrator he recorded no evidence, and expressly held that the Divisional Forest Officer was not obliged to refer the case for arbitration under cl. 9 of the contract, The trial was not of a proceeding in arbitration, but of a proceeding in exercise of supervisory or revisional jurisdiction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Revisional jurisdiction not arbitration; no evidence, one party subordinate, not award between contesting parties.

holdings.text: The order of the Divisional Forest Officer imposing Rs.8,500 compensation under r.15(1) cannot be sustained due to lack of determination under cl.9 of whether damage caused by contractor.

anchor.surface_text: It must therefore be held that the order passed by the Divisional Forest Officer imposing liability for compensation for damage done by illegal fellings cannot be sustained.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No proper dispute resolution under cl.9 preceding assessment under r.15.

holdings.text: The penalty of Rs.500 imposed under r.30(1) suffers the same infirmity and must be set aside, as no determination under cl.9 of contract breach.

anchor.surface_text: The second part of the order imposing penalty under r. 30 1 also suffers from the same infirmity. It is true that under the rule the Divisional Forest Officer had power to impose penalty in a sum not exceeding Rs. 500. But exercise of that power is conditioned by the existence of a breach by the forest contractor of any of the terms of the contract. Where a dispute arises whether there has been a breach of any of the terms of the contract, it is, for reasons already stated, to be determined by the Chief Conservator of Forests.

holdings.reasoning_summary: r.30 power conditioned on breach existence; disputed breach requires cl.9 determination.

holdings.text: The expression 'shall be referred to' in cl.9 means reference to the Chief Conservator as an arbitrator to decide the dispute.

anchor.surface_text: It is conceded, and in our judgment counsel is right in so conceding, that the expression shall be referred to means shall be referred to the Officer denominated as an arbitrator to decide the dispute.
But the appeal filed by the appellants must still fail on the grounds to be presently set out.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed; order of Divisional Forest Officer imposing compensation and penalty set aside

edges.explanation: Holding directly addresses the issue by stating High Court erred in holding DFO not authorized under r.15 due to coupe not being in reserved forest

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the appellants that the High Court has without any plea or evidence assumed that compensation under r. 15 1 could not be directed to be paid by the contractor for damage done in the coupe, for which he was given a contract, because the coupe was not included in a. reserved forest. The plea which appealed to the High Court was not raised in the petition, not in the objections to the Divisional Forest Officer in reply to the notice to show cause, not in the memorandum of appeal before the Conservator of Forests, not in the petition invoking the revisional jurisdiction of the Chief Conservator of Forests.
But the appeal filed by the appellants must still fail on the grounds to be presently set out.

edges.explanation: Holding h2 on r.15 infirmity supports h6 on r.30 suffering same infirmity lacking cl.9 determination

anchor.surface_text: able by the companytractor, but number to determine whether the companytractor, his servants or his agents have companymitted breach of the companytra

edges.explanation: Holding h2 that r.15(1) confers no authority on DFO when disputed addresses issue i2

anchor.surface_text: The rule does not confer upon the Divisional Forest Officer authority to determine, when a dispute is raised, whether damage has been caused in a reserved forest by the contractor, his agents or his servants. The rule only declares that for damage that may be done, by the contractor, his servants or agents, in the forest, the contractor shall be liable the rule also invests the Divisional Forest Officer with authority to determine the amount of compensation payable by the contractor, but not to determine whether the contractor, his servants or his agents have committed breach of the contract.
But the appeal filed by the appellants must still fail on the grounds to be presently set out.

anchor.surface_text: There is no inconsistency between cl. 9 of the contract and r. 15. It is unnecessary, therefore, to consider whether in case of inconsistency, the terms of the contract expressly setting out a certain covenant may supersede the terms of the rule.
But the appeal filed by the appellants must still fail on the grounds to be presently set out.

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Conservator of Forests did not even purport to act as an arbitrator he recorded no evidence, and expressly held that the Divisional Forest Officer was not obliged to refer the case for arbitration under cl. 9 of the contract, The trial was not of a proceeding in arbitration, but of a proceeding in exercise of supervisory or revisional jurisdiction.
But the appeal filed by the appellants must still fail on the grounds to be presently set out.
But the appeal filed by the appellants must still fail on the grounds to be presently set out.

anchor.surface_text: The second part of the order imposing penalty under r. 30 1 also suffers from the same infirmity. It is true that under the rule the Divisional Forest Officer had power to impose penalty in a sum not exceeding Rs. 500. But exercise of that power is conditioned by the existence of a breach by the forest contractor of any of the terms of the contract. Where a dispute arises whether there has been a breach of any of the terms of the contract, it is, for reasons already stated, to be determined by the Chief Conservator of Forests.
But the appeal filed by the appellants must still fail on the grounds to be presently set out.
But the appeal filed by the appellants must still fail on the grounds to be presently set out.
